questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after hitting her head on a metal beam. On examination, the wound has sharp edges but lacks undermining, and tissue bridges are visible. There is no significant underlying soft tissue present between the skin and the skull. What is the most likely type of injury?
questions.explanation:
Types of Laceration

Split Laceration (Option B)
  • These occur when skin is crushed between two objects, such as the scalp being compressed between the skull and a hard surface like the ground or a blunt object.
  • Seen on areas where the skin is close to bone, with minimal underlying tissue
  • E.g., scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, jaw, iliac crest, perineum, shin.
  • Lacerations without excessive skin crushing can have sharp edges, resembling incised wounds.
  • Also known as incised looking laceration.
  • These are not undermined and show tissue bridges.

Avulsion (Shearing Laceration) (Option C)
  • Caused by a shearing force at an acute angle, detaching skin or organs from their attachments.
  • The shearing and grinding force from a heavy object, like a lorry wheel passing over a limb, can cause the skin to separate from the underlying tissues, a condition known as avulsion or "flaying."
  • This often results in crushed muscles and fractured bones. The detached skin may have extensive abrasions due to the tyre’s friction, but one portion is still in continuity with adjacent skin.
  • Lacerations from shearing forces can leave the skin intact while separating the underlying soft tissue from the fascia, resulting in a blood-filled pocket. This type of injury is often observed on the back of the thighs in pedestrians hit by motor vehicles.

questions.text: A victim of an attack displays several injuries on the palms, flexor sides of the fingers, and interdigital spaces and are irregular and ragged cuts. Which of the following best describes the nature of these injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Passive defense injuries sustained while raising arms for protection

options.label: B
options.text: Active defense injuries sustained while attempting to grasp the weapon

options.label: D
options.text: Injuries caused by falling onto a sharp object

questions.correct_answer: B. Active defense injuries sustained while attempting to grasp the weapon
questions.explanation:
Active defense wounds

Passive defense wounds

Mechanism of injury

The victim tries to grasp the weapon.

The victim raises the arms, legs, or hands.

Site

  • Depends on the type of weapon.
  • A single-edged weapon causes a single cut on the palm or the bends of fingers or thumb.
  • A double-edged weapon produces cuts on both the palm and fingers.
  • A typical knife defense wound is seen between the base of the thumb and the index finger.
  • Extensor or ulnar surfaces of the forearms, wrists, back of the hands, knuckle. (vs Option A)
  • Rarely on the shin and feet.
  • Arms and posterior aspect of lower limbs and back.

Type of Injuries

Irregular and ragged cuts due to loosening of skin tension while gripping the knife.

Fractures of the carpal bones, metacarpals, and digits (mostly blunt trauma). (vs Option D)

Medicolegal importance

  • Defense wounds indicate homicide.
  • They are absent if the victim is:
    • Unconscious
    • Taken by surprise
    • Attacked from the back
    • Under the influence of drugs or alcohol

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was attacked with an axe and suffered a chop wound from it. Which of the following is true about a chop wound?

options.label: A
options.text: The wound is a laceration on the surface and does not involve the underlying bone

options.label: B
options.text: The dimensions of the wound do not correspond to the weapon size

options.label: C
options.text: The margins of the wound are always irregular

options.label: D
options.text: The heel of the axe leaves a deeper wound than the toe of the axe

questions.correct_answer: D. The heel of the axe leaves a deeper wound than the toe of the axe
questions.explanation:
Chop wounds/Slash wounds

  • These are deep gaping wounds inflicted by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon when applied with significant force.
  • It is a combination of blunt and sharp force injury.

Weapons used

  • Hatchet
  • Axe
  • Sword
  • Broad heavy knife
  • Chopper
  • Saber
  • Meat cleaver

Features of the wound
  • The axe's lower end (heel) strikes first, leaving a deeper wound than the upper end (toe).
  • It is an incised wound on skin with an underlying communited fracture or deep grove in the bone. (vs Option A)
  • Dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating blade. (vs Option B)
  • Margins are sharp and may have abrasions, bruising, and some lacerations with severe injury to underlying organs. (vs Option C)

Medicolegal importance

  • Most injuries are homicidal.
  • Frew are accidental by machinery (propeller injuries).
  • Rarely suicidal.
  • Wounds give details of the weapon used and the direction of attack.

questions.text: An old method of suicide conducted by Japanese samurai warriors as a ritual is shown below. Identify the cause of death in such cases.
questions.explanation:
Hara-kiri/Seppukku

  • Hara-kiri refers to an unusual method of suicide where the victim inflicts a single large stab wound on the abdomen.
  • It is associated with Japanese samurai warriors.

Characteristics of the wound

It is a single large stab wound made by the victim by moving the sword across the abdomen (usually left to right) and then turning it up to form an L-shape.

Mechanism of injury
  • The wound is made by a short sword while in a sitting position or
  • By falling onto a ceremonial sword.
  • A well-fixed knife can produce a wound like this, but only with enough momentum to do so.

Cause of death

  • The large wound leads to the intestines pulling out of the body, which causes a sudden drop in intrabdominal pressure and cardiac return.
  • This leads to sudden cardiac collapse and death.

questions.text: Assertion : The appearance and shape of stab wounds are significantly influenced by the orientation of Langer’s lines on the skin. Reason : Stab wounds that are parallel to Langer’s lines tend to be narrow and slit-shaped, while those that cut across the lines may gape due to skin elasticity and the tension created along these lines. Analyze the above statements and answer accordingly.

options.label: A
options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct and the reason is the right explanation

options.label: B
options.text: The assertion is wrong but the reason is correct

options.label: C
options.text: Both assertion and reason are wrong

options.label: D
options.text: The assertion is true but the reason is wrong

questions.correct_answer: A. Both assertion and reason are correct and the reason is the right explanation

questions.text: A forensic surgeon is examining multiple stab wounds on a homicide victim. The wounds are wedge-shaped as in the image: Which of the following weapons is likely the cause of the injury here?
questions.explanation:
Weapon used

Shape of wound
 

Single-edged weapon
  • Triangular or wedge-shaped surface wound
  • One side is sharp, and the other is rounded, blunt, or squared off

Double-edged weapon (Option C)
  • Elliptical or slit-like wound
  • Both sides are sharp or pointed

Round object

Circular wound

Pointed square weapon

Cross-shaped injury

Broken bottle (Option D)

Clusters of wounds of different shapes, sizes, depths, and irregular margins

Screwdriver

Slit-like stab wound with squared ends

Scissors (Option A)
  • Closed: flat “Z” shaped
  • Open: like a knife

Ice picks

Small, round, or slit-like

Fork

Group of 3-4 wounds depending on the prongs of the fork

Sites of concealed puncture wounds
  • Nostrils
  • Fontanelle
  • Fornix of upper eyelids
  • Axilla
  • Vagina
  • Rectum
  • Nape of the neck

questions.text: A forensic surgeon is examining a stab wound on a victim. Which of the following statement/s is/are true about the dimensions of the wound? 1. Breadth of the wound is equal to the thickness of the weapon. 2. Depth is the greatest dimension of a stab wound. 3. The edges of the wound are clean-cut. 4. The length of the wound is usually slightly less than the width.

A homicidal case with a stab wound over the abdomen is being examined. The weapon has passed through and through with a larger entry wound and a smaller exit wound. Which type of wound is this classified as?
questions.explanation:
Stab wound/Punctured wound

These are inflicted by penetration with long, narrow instruments having pointed (sometimes blunt) ends into the depth of the body, which is deeper than its length and width.

Weapons used

  • Knife (most common)
  • Pieces of glass (broken glass bottle)
  • Scissors
  • Screwdrivers
  • Pens
  • Ice picks
  • Forks

Types of stab wounds

  • Puncture wound: (Option A)
    • Soft tissues are involved
  • Penetrating wound: (Option C)
    • Enters a body cavity or a viscus
  • Perforating wound:
    • Through-and-through puncture wounds
    • The weapon enters the body from one side and comes out the other
    • The wound of entry is larger than the exit

Significance of the wound dimensions

  • Length is slightly less than the width of the weapon due to the stretching of the skin.
  • Breadth is more than the thickness of weapon due to gaping.
  • Depth, the greatest dimension of the wound, corresponds to the length of the weapon's blade, which has completely entered the body without perforation.
  • Margins or edges of the wound are clean cut with usually no abrasion or bruising.
    • Margins by a pointed or conical weapon have lacerated edges
    • If the hilt guard of the weapon strikes the skin, a regular, sharp, and well-defined patterned abrasion or bruising is formed

questions.text: A forensic pathologist examines a body and notes the following findings. What do these findings suggest?

options.label: A
options.text: The individual experienced a moment of hesitation before the fatal injury.

options.label: B
options.text: The injuries were caused by a blunt object.

options.label: C
options.text: The victim was attacked with a sharp instrument from a distance.

options.label: D
options.text: The wounds are consistent with self-inflicted injuries.

questions.correct_answer: A. The individual experienced a moment of hesitation before the fatal injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents for a follow-up appointment after undergoing surgery for an abdominal incision. The physician observes that the wound is beginning to heal, with granulation tissue forming in the wound bed. What is the most likely duration of healing indicated by the presence of vascularized granulation tissue?
questions.explanation:
Duration

Gross Findings

Microscopic Findings

Fresh

Red with clotted blood.

Capillary dilation, neutrophil margination and emigration, reactive changes in histiocytes.

12 hours

Margins red, swollen, and adherent; blood and lymph present.

Reactive changes in fibroblasts, monocytes in exudate. (Option B)

24 hours

Continuous layer of endothelial cells covers surface; scab of the dried clot.

Endothelial growth at edges; formation of vascular buds.

2–3 days

-

Formation of vascularized granulation tissue (Fibroblast activity) (Option C)

4–6 days

-

Formation of new fibrils. (Option D)

7 days

Scar formation.

Scar formation. (Option A)

Feature

Suicidal cut-throat wounds

Homicidal cut-throat wounds

Situation
  • Left side of the neck, crossing the front of the throat
  • High, above the thyroid cartilage
  • Both sides of the neck
  • Low, at or below the thyroid cartilage

Direction

Oblique, above downwards, left to right for right-handed persons

Transverse or below upwards

Number of Wounds

Multiple (20-30), superficial, parallel, merging with main wound

Multiple, intersecting at a deep level

Edges

Ragged due to overlapping superficial incisions

Sharp and clean-cut; beveling may be observed

Hesitation Cuts

Present

Absent

Wounds in Other Parts

May include cuts on wrists, groin, thighs

Severe injuries may be present on the head; no wrist wounds

Defense Wounds

Absent; may have unintentional cuts

Present unless the victim was caught unaware

Hands

May grasp the weapon firmly due to cadaveric spasm

Fragments of clothing or hair from the assailant may be grasped

Weapon at Site

Usually present

Typically absent

Vessels

Carotid artery may escape injury

Jugular vein and carotid artery likely cut

Blood Stains

May show splashing downward on clothes if in front of a mirror

Found on both palms from attempts to cover the wound

Circumstantial Evidence

Usually in quiet places (e.g., bedroom) with possible suicide notes

Scene disturbance and external footprints may be present

questions.text: During an autopsy of a 50-year-old male, the forensic pathologist observes a wound shown in the figure. Which of the following is correct regarding this type of wound?

options.label: A
options.text: Shallow at beginning, deeper towards end

questions.explanation:
Tailing

Bevelling
  • Deeper at the beginning due to greater knife pressure (the "head" of the wound). (Option A)
  • Becomes shallower toward the exit.
  • Indicating the cutting direction.
  • A wound created by an obliquely entering blade features a beveled margin on one side, and an undermined area on the other side.
  • Characteristic of sharp weapons
  • Associated with homicidal injuries.
  • Suggest the positions of the assailant and victim.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, the direction of the vehicle's movement can be inferred from the orientation of the skin flap, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely type of injury in this case?
questions.explanation:
Types of Laceration

Stretch laceration (Option C)

  • Caused by overstretching of fixed skin, leading to localized pressure and tearing, which creates a skin flap
  • Commonly seen in motor vehicle accidents, with the skin flap potentially indicating the vehicle's direction.
  • Can occur from kicking or bone deformity after a fracture, leading to compound injuries.
  • Results in irregular skin and tissue tearing, with a risk of foreign materials entering the wound.

Tear lacerations (Option D)

Cut Lacerations (Option B)
  • Result from impact with irregular or semi-sharp objects (e.g., car door handles, broken glass).
  • Characterized by a deeper starting point that tapers off towards the end, representing another form of overstretching.
  • Produced by heavy, sharp-edged instruments (e.g., axes, hatchets).
  • Typically, they have abraded margins with bruising, although the term "cut laceration" is often considered less precise.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of injury due to sharp force?
questions.explanation:
Blunt Force Injuries

Sharp Force Injuries
  • Abrasion: Superficial damage to the skin (scraping, rubbing off the outer layer).
  • Contusion: Bruise caused by blood vessels rupturing under the skin due to impact.
  • Laceration: Irregular tear in the skin or tissue caused by crushing or blunt trauma.
  • Fractures/Dislocations: Breaks or misalignment of bones due to strong blunt impact.
  • Incision: A clean-cut wound where the length is greater than the depth.
  • Stab Wound: A deep wound where the depth is greater than the length.
  • Chop Wound: A deep wound often associated with underlying fractures caused by heavy-bladed tools like an axe.

questions.text: During an autopsy, the forensic pathologist observes an injury on the thigh, which shows irregular edges, bruising, and embedded dirt. On further examination, the deeper tissues show uneven tearing, with visible nerve and blood vessel damage. What type of injury is most consistent with these findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Incised wound caused by a sharp object.

options.label: B
options.text: Laceration caused by blunt force trauma.

options.label: D
options.text: Puncture wound from a sharp object.

questions.correct_answer: B. Laceration caused by blunt force trauma.
questions.explanation:
Stellate

Round objects (e.g., hammer).

Crescentic

Objects with edges.

Linear

Long, thin objects (e.g., pipes)

Irregular/Y-shaped

Flat-surfaced objects

Accidental

Found on exposed body parts.

Homicidal

Found on non-accessible areas, typically the head.

Suicidal

Rare, usually on exposed parts, on the same side of the body.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the differences between a bruise and hypostasis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bruises are caused by ruptured vessels, but hypostasis from distension of vessels.

options.label: B
options.text: Bruises typically have clearly defined margins, but hypostasis merges with the surrounding area.

options.label: C
options.text: Bruises are often seen in the most dependent parts of the body, but hypostasis is only present at the site of injury.

options.label: D
options.text: Bruises do not cause elevation of the affected area, while hypostasis may cause swelling.

questions.correct_answer: A. Bruises are caused by ruptured vessels, but hypostasis from distension of vessels.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Bruise

Hypostasis/ Postmortem staining

Cause (Option A)

Ruptured vessels that may be deep or superficial.

Distension of vessels with blood in the dermis.

Site

(Option C)
  • At the site of and surrounding the injury.
  • May appear anywhere in the body.

Over extensive areas of the most dependant parts.

Appearance

(Option D)

Swollen.

No elevation of the affected area.

Epidermis

May be abraded.

Not abraded.

Margins

(Option B)

Merge with the surrounding area.

Clearly defined.

Color

Different colors according to the age of the bruise.

Uniform, bluish-purple.

Incision

  • Extravasation of blood into surrounding tissues and are firmly clotted.
  • Subcutaneous tissues are deep reddish-black.
  • Blood is seen in blood vessels.
  • Subcutaneous tissues are pale.

Antemortem bruise

Postmortem bruise

Swelling is present

Swelling is absent

Epithelium is damaged

No epithelial damage

Extravasation of blood is seen

No extravasation of blood

Coagulation is present

Coagulation is absemt

Tissues are infiltrated with blood

Not infiltrated with blood

Color changes are seen

Uniform color

Margins merge with the surrounding area

Margins are sharply demarcated

Appearance is more marked in victims who survive for sometime

Less marked appearance

questions.text: A medicolegal case of assault is being examined at the emergency with the following contusions. What is the most likely explanation for the appearance of these bruises?

options.label: A
options.text: Natural bruises due to physical trauma

options.label: B
options.text: Artificial bruising to falsely accuse someone

options.label: D
options.text: Bruising due to pre-existing medical condition

questions.correct_answer: B. Artificial bruising to falsely accuse someone
questions.explanation:
Artificial bruising

True bruising (Option A)
  • These are bruises created to make a false charge of assault.
  • They are usually present on accessible parts of the body.
  • They appear dark brown and irregular in shape.
  • Redness and inflammation are seen in the surrounding tissues.
  • Produced by the juice of a marking nut rubbed on the body.
  • Well-defined margins with small vesicles.
  • Itching is present.
  • Other substances used:
    • Plumbago
    • Madar/calotropis
    • Semicardium
  • The cause of true bruising is trauma.
  • They can be located anywhere in the body.
  • They undergo typical color changes.
  • Redness and inflammation are seen on the site.
  • They are usually round with well-defined, diffuse, and irregular margins with no vesicles.
  • They have extravasated blood as content and are not associated with itching.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a fall from a bike a day before, comes with the following findings.

A 30-year-old man presents with multiple bruises on his body following a fight. Upon examination, the physician notes a specific pattern of bruising on his back as shown: What is this type of bruise called?
questions.explanation:
Ectopic/percolated/migratory bruise

Patterned bruise
  • In deep bruises, blood tracks along the fascial planes and may cause the bruise at a different site.
  • This is also called percolated or migratory contusion.
  • Examples:
    • Spectacle hematoma (Option B) around the eyes after a blunt trauma to the forehead
    • Bruise behind the ear due to basal skull fracture known as Battle sign (Option A)
    • Bruise in thigh due to fractured pelvis
    • Bruise around knee due to a kick on calf
    • Grey Turner’s sign: Ecchymosis seen over the flank or side of the abdomen due to extensive retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
      Takes 24-48 hours to develop
    • Cullen’s sign: Bluish-black discoloration of the periumbilical skin due to extensive retroperitoneal or intraabdominal bleeding.
      Causes can be ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis
  • The shape and size of the bruise resemble a part of the object that caused it.
  • Shapes of bruises by different weapons:
    • A solid body like a hammer or fist causes round bruises
    • A doughnut bruise due to objects like a cricket ball
    • A rod, stick, or whip leads to two parallel, linear hemorrhages with normal skin in between known as railway line or tram line bruises
    • Blows from a whip are elongated and partially encircle a limb or the body
    • Tire patterns from an automobile accident (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a bruise on her thigh after bumping into a table. The bruise is noted to be blue. Upon further examination, she mentions that she noticed the bruise about a day ago. What is the most likely age of the bruise based on its current color?
questions.explanation:
Color of bruise

Age of bruise

Red (oxygenated blood)

Fresh bruise/ 1-2 hours

Blue (deoxyhemoglobin)

A few hours to 3 days

Bluish-black to brown (hemosiderin)

4th day (Option A)

Greenish (haematoidin/biliverdin)

5 to 6 days (Option B)

Yellow (bilirubin)

7 to 12 days

Normal

2 weeks (Option D)

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a fall. She gives a history of landing on her buttocks, where she has developed bruises. Which factor is NOT likely influencing the formation of her bruises?
questions.explanation:
Factor Effect
Age (Option A ruled out) Older individuals have more fragile blood vessels and thinner skin → easier bruising
Gender (Option B ruled out) Women tend to bruise more easily due to hormonal differences and less subcutaneous fat
Gravity shifting of blood (Option D ruled out) Blood from injured vessels can track down with gravity, affecting bruise location
Color of skin Does not affect bruise formation; may only influence visual perception of the bruise

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between postmortem and antemortem abrasions?

options.label: A
options.text: Antemortem abrasions are yellowish-white or pale, whereas postmortem abrasions are reddish-brown to dark brown in color.

options.label: B
options.text: Postmortem abrasions are typically found on bony prominences, while antemortem abrasions can occur on any part of the body.

options.label: C
options.text: Congestion is definitive of postmortem abrasions.

options.label: D
options.text: Both postmortem and antemortem abrasions exhibit bleeding with clot formation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Postmortem abrasions are typically found on bony prominences, while antemortem abrasions can occur on any part of the body.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Postmortem Abrasion

Antemortem Abrasion

Image

Intra-vital reaction or congestion (Option C)

Absent

Present

Site (Option B)

Typically found on bony prominences

Can occur on any part of the body

Color of abrasion

(Option A)

Yellowish-white or pale

Reddish-brown to dark brown

Scab formation

Absent or minimal

Present and well-formed

Exudates

Less or absent

Increased (due to inflammatory reaction)

Elevation (Scab)

Less raised

More raised due to active healing

Bleeding/ Color changes

(Option D)

No active bleeding

Active bleeding with clot formation

Healing process

No healing process

Healing starts with inflammation

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is being evaluated for injuries as part of a medico-legal case. During the examination, an abrasion wound is noted to be brown in color. Based on the appearance of the wound, what is the most likely time since the injury occurred?
questions.explanation:
Multiple Lines
  • Indicate the endpoint of the abrasion.
  • Reflect the direction of the applied force.

Uneven and Longitudinal Lines
  • Show irregularity at the end of the abrasion.
  • Suggest pulling or scraping of the skin.

Heaped-up or Aggregated Lines
  • Also known as Epithelial tags (Terminal tags)

  • Skin tissues dragged opposite to the force direction.
  • Point toward the end of the abrasion, indicating the force direction
  • E.g., tags heaped at the right end, if the force was left to right.

Time Post-Injury

Scab Color

Description

Before 12 hours

No scab

Exudate is still fluid and not yet dried.

12-24 hours

Bright red

Fresh blood and exudate are present.

2-3 days

Reddish-brown

Scab darkens, indicating it is ageing.

4-5 days

Brown

Scab continues to darken, turning brown.

6-7 days

Black

Scab becomes black, marking the late stage of healing.

After 7 days

Falls off

Scab typically falls off after this period.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the forensic findings given in the following image?

options.label: A
options.text: Pressure abrasion marks are always superficial and heal without scarring.

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous vertical force can cause damage to both the epidermis and underlying structures.

options.label: C
options.text: Ligature marks caused by hanging do not show epidermal crushing.

options.label: D
options.text: Abrasions from strangulation are typically caused by horizontal shearing forces.

questions.correct_answer: B. Continuous vertical force can cause damage to both the epidermis and underlying structures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was involved in a road traffic accident and presented with abrasion marks visible on his body. The abrasion pattern appears consistent with a distinct type of injury mechanism. Based on the image provided, what type of abrasion is most likely in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Scratch Abrasion (Linear Abrasion) (Option A)

Grazed Abrasion (Sliding Abrasion) (Option B)
  • Mechanism: Caused by tangential (side-to-side) force, producing a long and narrow abrasion.
  • Features: Linear in nature, with length being more significant than width.
  • Examples: Fingernail abrasion, thorn abrasion, and pin abrasion.
  • Mechanism: Occurs when skin slides over a rough surface, resulting in superficial scrapes.
  • Also Known As: Grinding abrasion, gravel rash, brush-burn.
  • Features: Seen in road traffic accidents or falls, especially on exposed areas like knees or elbows.

Imprint Abrasion (Patterned Abrasion) (Option C)

Pressure Abrasion (Crushing Abrasion) (Option D)
  • Mechanism: Results from compressive force applied perpendicular to the skin, leaving a distinct pattern of the object.
  • Also Known As Impact abrasion, contact abrasion, patterned abrasion.
  • Examples: Tyre marks, bite marks.
  • Mechanism: Caused by a continuous vertical force applied to the skin, crushing the epidermis.
  • Features: Deeper skin injuries are often seen with prolonged pressure, potentially leading to necrosis.
  • Examples: Ligature marks in hanging or strangulation
